elements.content: The combined use of microscopy methods and conventional X-ray crystallography offers new possibilities for the study of the self-assembly of coordination networks. This approach has been applied to the reactions of MCl2 salts (M = Co, Ni, Cu, Cd) and 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp). Copper gives [Cu(bpp)3Cl2]·2H2O (1), [Cu(bpp)2Cl]Cl·1.5H2O (2), and [Cu(bpp)2Cl2]·2.75H2O (3), that are 1D, 2D, and 3D polymers, respectively. Monitoring of the crystal growth shows that 1 and 2 are formed from the same mixtures in water, but at different times and conditions and can be interconverted (figure). Both 1 and 2 are transformed into 3 when suspended in EtOH.
elements.clean_text: The combined use of microscopy methods and conventional X-ray crystallography offers new possibilities for the study of the self-assembly of coordination networks. This approach has been applied to the reactions of MCl2 salts (M = Co, Ni, Cu, Cd) and 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp). Copper gives [Cu(bpp)3Cl2]⋅2H2O (1), [Cu(bpp)2Cl]Cl⋅1.5H2O (2), and [Cu(bpp)2Cl2]⋅2.75H2O (3), that are 1D, 2D, and 3D polymers, respectively. Monitoring of the crystal growth shows that 1 and 2 are formed from the same mixtures in water, but at different times and conditions and can be interconverted (figure). Both 1 and 2 are transformed into 3 when suspended in EtOH.

elements.content: The current interest for the self-assembly of networked coordination polymers, because of their potential properties as novel zeolite-like materials, for molecular sieving, ion exchange, gas storage, molecular sensing, and catalysis, has afforded many noteworthy two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) frames. However, the crystal engineering of networks with desired topologies and specific properties still remains a hard challenge, and the variety of factors that can influence a particular self-assembly process are not yet well understood. Indeed, besides a careful choice of suitable building blocks and reaction conditions, no model for the network formation from the solution is presently available. Because the final outcome of the crystallization can be driven by the details of the process, the investigation of these factors cannot be less important than the correct selection of the reagents.
elements.clean_text: The current interest for the self-assembly of networked coordination polymers, because of their potential properties as novel zeolite-like materials, for molecular sieving, ion exchange, gas storage, molecular sensing, and catalysis, has afforded many noteworthy two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) frames. However, the crystal engineering of networks with desired topologies and specific properties still remains a hard challenge, and the variety of factors that can influence a particular self-assembly process are not yet well understood. Indeed, besides a careful choice of suitable building blocks and reaction conditions, no model for the network formation from the solution is presently available. Because the final outcome of the crystallization can be driven by the details of the process, the investigation of these factors cannot be less important than the correct selection of the reagents.

elements.content: In this concern the use of microscopic techniques at different levels (optical or scanning probe microscopy, SPM), paralleling the crystallographic structural characterization of the products, can be useful for many purposes, including the following: (i) the study of the factors influencing the kinetic nucleation and crystal growth; (ii) the diagnostic monitoring of the crystallization process to reveal the possible crystal transformations with time or upon a change in the reaction conditions; (iii) the analysis of correlations between crystal structure and crystal morphology, and, particularly, the growth rates in different directions; (iv) the investigation of the surface phenomena under crystal transformation. Few studies concerning some of these features have been reported for metal complexes and, in particular, none, to our knowledge, for coordination polymers. Indeed, we have recently obtained interesting results from the AFM monitoring of the nanoporous behavior of a catenated spongelike 3D coordination network.
elements.clean_text: In this concern the use of microscopic techniques at different levels (optical or scanning probe microscopy, SPM), paralleling the crystallographic structural characterization of the products, can be useful for many purposes, including the following: (i) the study of the factors influencing the kinetic nucleation and crystal growth; (ii) the diagnostic monitoring of the crystallization process to reveal the possible crystal transformations with time or upon a change in the reaction conditions; (iii) the analysis of correlations between crystal structure and crystal morphology, and, particularly, the growth rates in different directions; (iv) the investigation of the surface phenomena under crystal transformation. Few studies concerning some of these features have been reported for metal complexes and, in particular, none, to our knowledge, for coordination polymers. Indeed, we have recently obtained interesting results from the AFM monitoring of the nanoporous behavior of a catenated spongelike 3D coordination network.

elements.content: We have therefore investigated, using the above approach, the networking ability of the conformationally flexible bidentate ligand 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) with the chlorides of M2+ cations (M = Co, Ni, Cu, Cd), in variated crystallization conditions. We report here on these studies, carried out at a phenomenological level, that have lead to some interesting and unpredictable results.
elements.clean_text: We have therefore investigated, using the above approach, the networking ability of the conformationally flexible bidentate ligand 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) with the chlorides of M2+ cations (M = Co, Ni, Cu, Cd), in variated crystallization conditions. We report here on these studies, carried out at a phenomenological level, that have lead to some interesting and unpredictable results.

elements.content: Different polymeric species have been obtained, depending on the solvent system. Two main bulk products have been isolated with all the metal salts by the direct reactions carried out using a bpp to MCl2 molar ratio of 2:1, that is, the one-dimensional (1D) polymer [M(bpp)3Cl2] from water solutions, and the interpenetrated diamondoid network [M(bpp)2Cl2] from mixed solvent systems involving water and an organic solvent (alcohols, acetone, dichloromethane, and others). We have then focused our investigation on the copper system. However, in the attempt of obtaining the 1D polymer from water, we have also observed the preliminary formation of crystals of a third species. We therefore describe here the structures of the three copper polymers, namely, [Cu(bpp)3Cl2]·2H2O (1), [Cu(bpp)2Cl]Cl·1.5H2O (2), and [Cu(bpp)2Cl2]·2.75H2O (3) that are 1D, 2D, and 3D polymers, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Different polymeric species have been obtained, depending on the solvent system. Two main bulk products have been isolated with all the metal salts by the direct reactions carried out using a bpp to MCl2 molar ratio of 2:1, that is, the one-dimensional (1D) polymer [M(bpp)3Cl2] from water solutions, and the interpenetrated diamondoid network [M(bpp)2Cl2] from mixed solvent systems involving water and an organic solvent (alcohols, acetone, dichloromethane, and others). We have then focused our investigation on the copper system. However, in the attempt of obtaining the 1D polymer from water, we have also observed the preliminary formation of crystals of a third species. We therefore describe here the structures of the three copper polymers, namely, [Cu(bpp)3Cl2]⋅2H2O (1), [Cu(bpp)2Cl]Cl⋅1.5H2O (2), and [Cu(bpp)2Cl2]⋅2.75H2O (3) that are 1D, 2D, and 3D polymers, respectively.

elements.content: This system has been the object of growth studies using optical microscopy. We have observed that the formation of 1 is preceded by the nucleation and growth of crystals of 2, not observed in the bulk reactions of the other salts. Both 1 and 2 are obtained from water solutions of the reagents, but in successive periods of time. The crystal growth and the solid transformation mediated by the solvent have been followed by means of an optical microscope coupled to a CCD camera with automatic time series image acquisition. The pictures show (Figure ) that after a few hours a large amount of dark-blue crystals of 2 were formed as the unique product, and then the system evolved to 1, which gives larger crystals of a lighter blue color with a characteristic morphology, while the crystals of 2 were progressively destroyed. The transformation (at room temperature) takes place with different rates at different ligand-to-metal molar ratios. Relatively high concentrations of the reagents and/or lower ligand-to-metal ratios favor the formation of crystals of 2 at the expense of 1. When the proper conditions are used, therefore, the 2 → 1 transformation can be stopped or driven to completion so that we were able to obtain pure crystal samples of both species suitable for a single-crystal X-ray analysis.
elements.clean_text: This system has been the object of growth studies using optical microscopy. We have observed that the formation of 1 is preceded by the nucleation and growth of crystals of 2, not observed in the bulk reactions of the other salts. Both 1 and 2 are obtained from water solutions of the reagents, but in successive periods of time. The crystal growth and the solid transformation mediated by the solvent have been followed by means  of an optical microscope coupled to a CCD camera with automatic time series image acquisition. The pictures show (Figure ) that after a few hours a large amount of dark-blue crystals of 2 were formed as the unique product, and then the system evolved to 1, which gives larger crystals of a lighter blue color with a characteristic morphology, while the crystals of 2 were progressively destroyed. The transformation (at room temperature) takes place with different rates at different ligand-to-metal molar ratios. Relatively high concentrations of the reagents and/or lower ligand-to-metal ratios favor the formation of crystals of 2 at the expense of 1. When the proper conditions are used, therefore, the 2 → 1 transformation can be stopped or driven to completion so that we were able to obtain pure crystal samples of both species suitable for a single-crystal X-ray analysis.

elements.content: Monitoring of the crystal transformation2 → 1; small crystals on the background belong to 2. Crystals of 1 nucleated approximately after 2 h since solution mixing (elapsed time reported; 2.5 mm on the long side).
elements.clean_text: 1  Monitoring of the crystal transformation2 → 1; small crystals on the background belong to 2. Crystals of 1 nucleated approximately after 2 h since solution mixing (elapsed time reported; 2.5 mm on the long side).

elements.content: View of a single zigzag chain in coumpound1 (top) and of the interdigitation of the polymers (bottom) in the (0 0 1) plane (horizontal axis a, vertical axis b). The coordination geometry is distorted octahedral and relevant bond parameters are as follows:  Cu−N 2.050(4)−2.054(4) Å; Cu−Cl 2.795(1)−2.802(1) Å.
elements.clean_text: 2  View of a single zigzag chain in coumpound1 (top) and of the interdigitation of the polymers (bottom) in the (0 0 1) plane (horizontal axis a, vertical axis b). The coordination geometry is distorted octahedral and relevant bond parameters are as follows: Cu-N 2.050(4)-2.054(4) Å; Cu-Cl 2.795(1)-2.802(1) Å.

elements.content: View of a single (4,4) layer in2 (top) and of the 3D architecture formed by interpenetration of the three sets of layers down the a axis (bottom). The stacking of the layers is ABAB for all three sets. The open channels running down [1 0 0] are evidenced. Relevant bond parameters are as follows:  Cu−N 2.015(8)−2.089(8) Å; Cu−Cl 2.499(3)−2.537(4) Å.
elements.clean_text: 3  View of a single (4,4) layer in2 (top) and of the 3D architecture formed by interpenetration of the three sets of layers down the a axis (bottom). The stacking of the layers is ABAB for all three sets. The open channels running down [1 0 0] are evidenced. Relevant bond parameters are as follows: Cu-N 2.015(8)-2.089(8) Å; Cu-Cl 2.499(3)-2.537(4) Å.

elements.content: The structure of compound 1 consists of zigzag Cu(bpp) chains all running in the [1 0 0] direction and exhibiting also two monocoordinated ligands per metal atom (Figure ); these parallel 1D polymers (with a period equal to a, 17.19 Å) are arranged in (0 0 1) planes with high interdigitation of their dangling ligands. The layers of interdigitated chains stack along the c crystallographic axis, interacting in this direction only via π−π contacts involving the uncoordinated pyridyl rings. Thermogravimetric analysis shows that compound 1 is stable up to ≈120 °C.
elements.clean_text: The structure of compound 1 consists of zigzag Cu(bpp) chains all running in the [1 0 0] direction and exhibiting also two monocoordinated ligands per metal atom (Figure ); these parallel 1D polymers (with a period equal to a, 17.19 Å) are arranged in (0 0 1) planes  with high interdigitation of their dangling ligands. The layers of interdigitated chains stack along the c crystallographic axis, interacting in this direction only via π-π contacts involving the uncoordinated pyridyl rings. Thermogravimetric analysis shows that compound 1 is stable up to ~120 °C.

elements.content: The structure of 2 consists of tassellated (4,4) sheets (Figure , top) based on five-coordinated copper atoms in a square-pyramidal geometry (with four equatorial pyridyl groups and an axial chloride ion). There are three almost identical but crystallographically independent sets of sheets (in red, green, and blue in Figure , bottom), which lie parallel to the (0 1 0) (red) and (0 0 1) (green and blue) planes and display “inclined” interpenetration, resulting in an overall 3D array. The space-filling model of 2 down the a axis, illustrated in Figure (bottom), clearly shows that there are open channels within the network (four per unit cell of free volume of ≈280 Å3 each) occupied by the included water molecules and free Cl- anions (omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: The structure of 2 consists of tassellated (4,4) sheets (Figure , top) based on five-coordinated copper atoms in a square-pyramidal geometry (with four equatorial pyridyl groups and an axial chloride ion). There are three almost identical but crystallographically independent sets of sheets (in red, green, and blue in Figure , bottom), which lie parallel to the (0 1 0) (red) and (0 0 1) (green and blue) planes and display "inclined" interpenetration, resulting in an overall 3D array. The space-filling model of 2 down the a axis, illustrated in Figure  (bottom), clearly shows that there are open channels within the network (four per unit cell of free volume of ~280 Å3 each) occupied by the included water molecules and free Cl- anions (omitted for clarity).

elements.content: Despite the different stoichiometry, the 2 → 1 transformation is spontaneous also if it implies that part of the copper remains unreacted; 1 is clearly favored by an excess of bpp, but the formation of 2 is observed even at a large ligand-to-metal stoichiometric excess. The process seems entropy-favored but the mechanism is not clear.
elements.clean_text: Despite the different stoichiometry, the 2 → 1 transformation is spontaneous also if it implies that part of the copper remains unreacted; 1 is clearly favored by an excess of bpp, but the formation of 2 is observed even at a large ligand-to-metal stoichiometric excess. The process seems entropy-favored but the mechanism is not clear.

elements.content:
Differently from the behavior in water solution, the presence of ethanol or other organic solvents (methanol, acetone, and CH2Cl2) leads to the formation of crystals of 3 only.

The structure of 3 consists of four interpenetrating diamondlike networks of octahedral metal centers linked by bpp bridges, which occupy the four equatorial positions of the copper coordination sphere, which is completed by two Cl- anions (in the trans positions) (see Figure , left). The four independent frameworks are related by translation along the c tetragonal axis in the usual interpenetration topology for diamondoid frames. However, in a set of adamantane cages the ligands display patterns that are rotated by 90° about c upon passing from one frame to the successive one (Figure , right). This creates isolated cavities to host the solvent molecules, in contrast to the typical open channels in the normal “parallely” interpenetrated n-fold diamondlike nets. Indeed, despite interpenetration, the coordination network of 3 still contains large voids, filled by solvated molecules, mainly of water.
elements.clean_text:
Differently from the behavior in water solution, the presence of ethanol or other organic solvents (methanol, acetone, and CH2Cl2) leads to the formation of crystals of 3 only. 

The structure of 3 consists of four interpenetrating diamondlike networks of octahedral metal centers linked by bpp bridges, which occupy the four equatorial positions of the copper coordination sphere, which is completed by two Cl- anions (in the trans positions) (see Figure , left). The four independent frameworks are related by translation along the c tetragonal axis in the usual interpenetration topology for diamondoid frames. However, in a set of adamantane cages the ligands display patterns that are rotated by 90° about c upon passing from one frame to the successive one (Figure , right). This creates isolated cavities to host the solvent molecules, in contrast to the typical open channels in the normal "parallely" interpenetrated n-fold diamondlike nets. Indeed, despite interpenetration, the coordination network of 3 still contains large voids, filled by solvated molecules, mainly of water.

elements.content: View of the 4-fold interpenetrated diamondoid network in compound3 (left) and of the isolated solvent-containing chambers represented down the [0 0 1] direction. Relevant bond parameters are as follows:  Cu−N 2.036(7)−2.069(5) Å; Cu−Cl 2.679(2)−2.832(3) Å.
elements.clean_text: 4  View of the 4-fold interpenetrated diamondoid network in compound3 (left) and of the isolated solvent-containing chambers represented down the [0 0 1] direction. Relevant bond parameters are as follows: Cu-N 2.036(7)-2.069(5) Å; Cu-Cl 2.679(2)-2.832(3) Å.

elements.content: The great influence of the solvent in this system has been confirmed by direct observation by optical microscopy of the trasformation to compound 3 of crystals of both 1 and 2 suspended in ethanol, according to the overall Scheme. Likely ethanol has a templating effect on the formation of 3, by filling the isolated cavities. All the transformations have been confirmed by XRPD methods.
elements.clean_text: The great influence of the solvent in this system has been confirmed by direct observation by optical microscopy of the trasformation to compound 3 of crystals of both 1 and 2 suspended in ethanol, according to the overall Scheme. Likely ethanol has a templating effect on the formation of 3, by filling the isolated cavities. All the transformations have been confirmed by XRPD methods.

elements.content: Top:  correlation between crystal morphology and structure in compound1. Bottom:  AFM monitoring of the crystal growth of 1 (scan size 2 × 2 μm2) showing tangential accretion with monomolecular layers around a complex dislocation source.
elements.clean_text: 5  Top: correlation between crystal morphology and structure in compound1. Bottom: AFM monitoring of the crystal growth of 1 (scan size 2 × 2 μm2) showing tangential accretion with monomolecular layers around a complex dislocation source.

A morphological analysis has also been carried out, with face indexing of all the crystalline species to correlate the crystallographic parameters, and therefore the polymerization vectors of the networks, to the growth directions of crystals.
elements.clean_text: A morphological analysis has also been carried out, with face indexing of all the crystalline species to correlate the crystallographic parameters, and therefore the polymerization vectors of the networks, to the growth directions of crystals.

elements.content: This has shown the following features:  in compound 3 the highest growing rate is coincident with the tetragonal axis, along which the adamantanoid cages are interpenetrated. The most surprising result, however, is that in 1 the preferential growth direction of the crystals is along [0 1 0], which corresponds to the packing direction of the 1D polymers, coincident with the interdigitation of the chains, and not with the direction of extension of the chains along [1 0 0] (see Figure , top). Indeed, the periodic bond chain theory (PBC) stresses the role, clearly recognized and tested, of intermolecular forces in determining the morphology of crystals but, on this ground, we would expect the [1 0 0] growth direction to be the preferred one, owing to the more intense metal−ligand interactions.
elements.clean_text: This has shown the following features: in compound 3 the highest growing rate is coincident with the tetragonal axis, along which the adamantanoid cages are interpenetrated. The most surprising result, however, is that in 1 the preferential growth direction of the crystals is along [0 1 0], which corresponds to the packing direction of the 1D polymers, coincident with the interdigitation of the chains, and not with the direction of extension of the chains along [1 0 0] (see Figure , top). Indeed, the periodic bond chain theory (PBC) stresses the role, clearly recognized and tested,  of intermolecular forces in determining the morphology of crystals but, on this ground, we would expect the [1 0 0] growth direction to be the preferred one, owing to the more intense metal-ligand interactions.

elements.content: Finally, preliminary studies with in situ AFM monitoring of the crystal growth of 1 reveals that this proceeds by tangential accretion of monomolecular layers (height of half of the c axis) corresponding to the (0 0 2) plane (Figure , bottom). Also on this scale the anisotropy of the interactions in the (0 0 1) plane shows growth rates ν[0 1 0] > ν[1 0 0], with profiles resembling those of the mature crystals.
elements.clean_text: Finally, preliminary studies with in situ AFM monitoring of the crystal growth of 1 reveals that this proceeds by tangential accretion of monomolecular layers (height of half of the c axis) corresponding to the (0 0 2) plane (Figure , bottom). Also on this scale the anisotropy of the interactions in the (0 0 1) plane shows growth rates ν[0 1 0] > ν[1 0 0], with profiles resembling those of the mature crystals.

elements.content: We have pointed our attention to these kinds of studies about the crystallogenesis of the polymeric materials because they may be useful in achieving a better understanding of the driving factors operative in the self-assembly of the coordination networks. Besides the interesting features described here, this approach seems promising for general application to a variety of polymeric systems and supramolecular arrays.
elements.clean_text: We have pointed our attention to these kinds of studies about the crystallogenesis of the polymeric materials because they may be useful in achieving a better understanding of the driving factors operative in the self-assembly of the coordination networks. Besides the interesting features described here, this approach seems promising for general application to a variety of polymeric systems and supramolecular arrays.

metadata.title:
Monitoring the Crystal Growth and
Interconversion of New Coordination
Networks in the Self-assembly of MCl2
Salts (M = Co, Ni, Cu, Cd) and
1,3-Bis(4-pyridyl)propane
